title: Why did the 1970s produce so many great rock musicians like Bowie, Freddie Mercury, Elton John and Billy Joel? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think a big part of it was the existence of the great British rock musicians from the 1960s. As Rob Halkovich mentioned, there was huge influence in Britain from the great black blues and R&B musicians, and this resulted the 60s bands I mention. The Beatles in particular but also the Rolling Stones, the Who, the Kinks, the Yardbirds, and many more were HUGE influences on the likes of David Bowie and Billy Joel, among numerous others. And as was mentioned by Andrew Chapman, the corporate greed at both the record companies and the radio stations had not yet fully materialized. So musicians were free to be creative and build upon what their predecessors had built, making music that’s just as good if not better. I agree that neither Dark Side of the Moon nor Stairway to Heaven would have made it 10 years later. Neither would have Elton John’s album “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road” or David Bowie’s “Ziggy Stardust” or Queen’s “A Night at the Opera.” The 1980s did produce some very good music, but thanks to corporate greed’s tightening noose, the great rock musicians of the 1980s were fewer and not as great. In a nutshell, corporate greed is deadly poison to creativity. This got worse and worse through the 1990s. I consider it a miracle that bands like Alice in Chains or Nirvana were even possible. And now, well, I don’t think there’s more than a dozen or so musicians from this millennium that I’ve given space in my music collection. :(

Dan Stewart-Martin makes a good point to start. For those of us alive then, we tend to forget the bad stuff, and for those who weren’t alive yet, you probably have never heard it! The ’70s was also the last great time of relative freedom for music artists. While being beholden to record labels, the labels still largely allowed the musicians a lot of latitude and typically gave promising ones a few albums to develop their sound. By the late ’70s and certainly the 1980s, the corporate pressure of record labels pushed financial returns… more hit songs, more sales, quicker turnaround between albums, etc. All of this diminished the freedom of the artists in their music. A legendary piece like Dark Side of the Moon may very well have never happened just ten years later, and likewise for the epic “Stairway to Heaven,” which was waaaaay too long for ’80s radio. Corporate pressure also infested radio by the late ’70s and ‘80s, which meant that FM stations and deejays didn’t have their freedom either. Corporate-driven playlists started to replace the independence of deejays to pick their own songs. More and more major stations fell under the ownership of corporate conglomerates, which led to stations across the country playing much of the same stuff in homogeny. By the early ‘70s, FM stations had gained popularity by being more adventurous in their music (compared to the pop-focused AM stations), but by the mid-’80s this was almost entirely lost, with the exception of a few major indie and college stations. (In this paragraph, I’m referring to radio in the U.S.; I can’t speak to radio at that time in other countries.) The last factor is that rock music was still relatively new. Think of it this way… halfway through the 1970s, it was only 20 years old. And rock music as it had become (as opposed to rock ’n’ roll) was really only about ten years old, corresponding to the “British Invasion” in 1964-’65. Musically, there was vast territory open for exploration, which led to the diversity among the artists you mention in your question. In 1965, most rock music was quite similar; less than 15 years later, you had punk, progressive rock, glam, heavy metal, new wave, soft rock, arena rock, hard rock, and pop rock. That’s a pretty amazing transformation in such a short time.
